qas.question: Which Muslim denominations are the most dominant?
What are the two main things differentiating Sunni and Shia?

answers.text: how the life of the ummah ("faithful") should be governed, and the role of the imam

qas.question: Who is believed, among Sunnis,  to be the political successor of the Prophet?

answers.text: father of the Prophet's favourite wife

qas.question: Who was Ali ibn Abi Talib?

answers.text: husband of the Prophet's daughter Fatimah

qas.question: What are two fringe denominations of Islam?
What denominations agree on how the faithful should be governed?
What do the Sunni consider Ibn Abi Talib to the successor of?
What type of sucessor do the Shia believe Abu Bakr was?

context: The two main denominations of Islam are the <a0_0><b5_0><b6_0>Sunni and Shia<b6_0/><b5_0/><a0_0/> sects. They differ primarily upon of <a1_0>how the life of the ummah ("faithful") should be governed, and the role of the imam<a1_0/>. These two main differences stem from the understanding of which hadith are to interpret the Quran. Sunnis believe the <b8_0>true political successor<b8_0/> of the Prophet in Sunnah is based on ٍShura (consultation) at the Saqifah which selected <a2_0>Abu Bakr<a2_0/>, <a3_0>father of the Prophet's favourite wife<a3_0/>, 'A'ishah, to lead the Islamic community while the religious succession ceased to exist on account of finality of Prophethood. Shia on the other hand believe that the true <b7_0>political as well as religious<b7_0/> successor is Ali ibn Abi Talib, <a4_0>husband of the Prophet's daughter Fatimah<a4_0/> (designated by the Prophet).
